clusters.title: Study Links Higher Tyrosine Levels to Shorter Lifespan in Men
clusters.summary: A comprehensive study involving over 270,000 participants has revealed a potential connection between elevated levels of the amino acid tyrosine and a reduced lifespan in men. Tyrosine, commonly found in protein-rich foods and marketed as a cognitive supplement, may have implications for health and longevity. This finding raises questions about the effects of dietary supplements on lifespan and overall well-being.

items.title: Study suggests one common amino acid may affect how long men live
items.description: A large new study suggests that higher levels of a common amino acid called tyrosine may be linked to a shorter lifespan in men.

items.title: Popular brain supplement linked to shorter lifespan in men
items.description: A massive study of more than 270,000 people has uncovered a surprising link between a common amino acid and how long men live. Researchers found that higher levels of tyrosine—an amino acid found in protein-rich foods and often marketed as a focus-boosting supplement—were associated with shorter life expectancy in men, potentially trimming nearly a year off lifespan.

clusters.title: Menopause linked to grey matter loss in key brain regions
clusters.summary: A major study suggests menopause is linked to changes in brain structure, mental health, and sleep. Brain scans revealed grey matter loss in areas tied to memory and emotional regulation, while many women reported increased anxiety, depression, and fatigue. Hormone therapy did not reverse these effects, though it may slow age-related declines in reaction speed.

items.title: Menopause linked to grey matter loss in key brain regions
items.description: A major study suggests menopause is linked to changes in brain structure, mental health, and sleep. Brain scans revealed grey matter loss in areas tied to memory and emotional regulation, while many women reported increased anxiety, depression, and fatigue. Hormone therapy did not reverse these effects, though it may slow age-related declines in reaction speed. Researchers say menopause could represent an important turning point for brain health.

clusters.title: Alzheimer’s may trick the brain into erasing its own memories
clusters.summary: Alzheimer’s may destroy memory by flipping a single molecular switch that tells neurons to prune their own connections. Researchers found that both amyloid beta and inflammation converge on the same receptor, triggering synapse loss. Surprisingly, neurons aren’t passive victims—they actively respond to these signals.

items.title: Alzheimer’s may trick the brain into erasing its own memories
items.description: Alzheimer’s may destroy memory by flipping a single molecular switch that tells neurons to prune their own connections. Researchers found that both amyloid beta and inflammation converge on the same receptor, triggering synapse loss. Surprisingly, neurons aren’t passive victims—they actively respond to these signals. Targeting this receptor could offer a new way to protect memory beyond current amyloid-focused drugs.

clusters.title: Blood test predicts which bladder cancer patients may safely skip surgery
clusters.summary: Circulating tumor DNA, or ctDNA, can predict metastatic risk in patients who receive bladder-sparing treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer, but it is not a good predictor of local recurrence within the bladder, according to new data presented today by Fox Chase Cancer Center researchers.

items.title: Blood test predicts which bladder cancer patients may safely skip surgery
items.description: Circulating tumor DNA, or ctDNA, can predict metastatic risk in patients who receive bladder-sparing treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer, but it is not a good predictor of local recurrence within the bladder, according to new data presented today by Fox Chase Cancer Center researchers.

clusters.title: Heightened anxiety sensitivity linked to memory issues in late-life depression
clusters.summary: A specific fear of bodily sensations often accompanies depression in older adults. This heightened distress is associated with lower cognitive scores, interrupted sleep, and a reduced overall quality of life, according to a recent study.

items.title: Heightened anxiety sensitivity linked to memory issues in late-life depression
items.description: A specific fear of bodily sensations often accompanies depression in older adults. This heightened distress is associated with lower cognitive scores, interrupted sleep, and a reduced overall quality of life, according to a recent study.

clusters.title: Scientists discover protein that rejuvenates aging brain cells
clusters.summary: A newly identified protein may hold the key to rejuvenating aging brain cells. Researchers found that boosting DMTF1 can restore the ability of neural stem cells to regenerate, even when age-related damage has set in. Without it, these cells struggle to renew and support memory and learning.

items.title: Scientists discover protein that rejuvenates aging brain cells
items.description: A newly identified protein may hold the key to rejuvenating aging brain cells. Researchers found that boosting DMTF1 can restore the ability of neural stem cells to regenerate, even when age-related damage has set in. Without it, these cells struggle to renew and support memory and learning. The findings raise hopes for treatments that could slow or even reverse aspects of brain aging.

clusters.title: Study compiles 30 years of adhesion GPCR modulators and their key concentrations
clusters.summary: Adhesion GPCRs are a large class of surface proteins that recognize chemical and mechanical stimuli in the body. The rapidly expanding body of knowledge on the therapeutic targeting of these receptors is raising hopes for clinical application in the near future. Although no medicinal products targeting these receptors have yet been approved, several adhesion GPCR modulators are available and show potential for translation into clinical use.

items.title: Study compiles 30 years of adhesion GPCR modulators and their key concentrations
items.description: Adhesion GPCRs are a large class of surface proteins that recognize chemical and mechanical stimuli in the body. The rapidly expanding body of knowledge on the therapeutic targeting of these receptors is raising hopes for clinical application in the near future. Although no medicinal products targeting these receptors have yet been approved, several adhesion GPCR modulators are available and show potential for translation into clinical use. Modulators are crucial for the regulation of metabolic pathways and play a major role in pharmacology by enabling the targeted control of receptor activity.

clusters.title: Why some kids struggle with math even when they try hard
clusters.summary: A new Stanford study suggests math struggles may be about more than numbers. Children who had difficulty with math were less likely to adjust their thinking after making mistakes during number comparison tasks. Brain imaging showed weaker activity in regions that help monitor errors and guide behavioral changes.

items.title: Why some kids struggle with math even when they try hard
items.description: A new Stanford study suggests math struggles may be about more than numbers. Children who had difficulty with math were less likely to adjust their thinking after making mistakes during number comparison tasks. Brain imaging showed weaker activity in regions that help monitor errors and guide behavioral changes. These brain patterns could predict which children were more likely to struggle.

clusters.title: Intermittent fasting fails to beat standard dieting for weight loss
clusters.summary: Intermittent fasting has become one of the most talked-about weight loss trends in recent years, promising dramatic results with simple changes to when you eat. But a major Cochrane review suggests the reality may be far less exciting. After analyzing 22 clinical trials involving nearly 2,000 adults, researchers found that intermittent fasting did not produce significantly more weight loss than standard diet advice or even no structured plan at all.

items.title: Intermittent fasting fails to beat standard dieting for weight loss
items.description: Intermittent fasting has become one of the most talked-about weight loss trends in recent years, promising dramatic results with simple changes to when you eat. But a major Cochrane review suggests the reality may be far less exciting. After analyzing 22 clinical trials involving nearly 2,000 adults, researchers found that intermittent fasting did not produce significantly more weight loss than standard diet advice or even no structured plan at all.

clusters.title: Depression may be the brain’s early warning sign of Parkinson’s or dementia
clusters.summary: Depression in older adults may sometimes signal the early stages of Parkinson’s disease or Lewy body dementia. Researchers found that depression often appears years before diagnosis and remains elevated long afterward, unlike in other chronic illnesses. This suggests depression may reflect early brain changes rather than emotional distress alone.

items.title: Depression may be the brain’s early warning sign of Parkinson’s or dementia
items.description: Depression in older adults may sometimes signal the early stages of Parkinson’s disease or Lewy body dementia. Researchers found that depression often appears years before diagnosis and remains elevated long afterward, unlike in other chronic illnesses. This suggests depression may reflect early brain changes rather than emotional distress alone.

clusters.title: New psychology research reveals a vicious cycle involving smartphone use and feelings of disconnection
clusters.summary: A new study published in Addictive Behaviors provides evidence that excessive smartphone use and feelings of disconnection fuel a daily cycle. When college students reach for their phones for relief, they tend to feel more detached the following day.

items.title: New psychology research reveals a vicious cycle involving smartphone use and feelings of disconnection
items.description: A new study published in Addictive Behaviors provides evidence that excessive smartphone use and feelings of disconnection fuel a daily cycle. When college students reach for their phones for relief, they tend to feel more detached the following day.

clusters.title: Male sex, older age predict poor outcomes in seniors with HFmrEF/HFpEF
clusters.summary: Considerable sex disparities are reported in elderly patients with heart failure with mildly reduced or preserved ejection fraction (HFmrEF/HFpEF), with male sex and older age predicting poor outcomes, according to a study published online Jan. 8 in ESC Heart Failure.

items.title: Male sex, older age predict poor outcomes in seniors with HFmrEF/HFpEF
items.description: Considerable sex disparities are reported in elderly patients with heart failure with mildly reduced or preserved ejection fraction (HFmrEF/HFpEF), with male sex and older age predicting poor outcomes, according to a study published online Jan. 8 in ESC Heart Failure.

clusters.title: Common pneumonia bacterium may fuel Alzheimer’s disease
clusters.summary: A common bacterium best known for causing pneumonia and sinus infections may also play a surprising role in Alzheimer’s disease. Researchers found that Chlamydia pneumoniae can invade the retina and brain, where it sparks inflammation, nerve cell death, and the buildup of amyloid-beta—the hallmark protein linked to Alzheimer’s. Higher levels of the bacterium were found in people with Alzheimer’s, especially those carrying the high-risk APOE4 gene, and were tied to more severe cognitive decline.

items.title: Common pneumonia bacterium may fuel Alzheimer’s disease
items.description: A common bacterium best known for causing pneumonia and sinus infections may also play a surprising role in Alzheimer’s disease. Researchers found that Chlamydia pneumoniae can invade the retina and brain, where it sparks inflammation, nerve cell death, and the buildup of amyloid-beta—the hallmark protein linked to Alzheimer’s. Higher levels of the bacterium were found in people with Alzheimer’s, especially those carrying the high-risk APOE4 gene, and were tied to more severe cognitive decline.

clusters.title: Alzheimer’s may begin with a silent drop in brain blood flow
clusters.summary: Subtle changes in brain blood flow and oxygen use are closely linked to hallmark signs of Alzheimer’s, including amyloid plaques and memory-related brain shrinkage. Simple, noninvasive scans may one day help spot risk earlier—by looking at the brain’s vascular health, not just its plaques.

items.title: Alzheimer’s may begin with a silent drop in brain blood flow
items.description: Subtle changes in brain blood flow and oxygen use are closely linked to hallmark signs of Alzheimer’s, including amyloid plaques and memory-related brain shrinkage. Simple, noninvasive scans may one day help spot risk earlier—by looking at the brain’s vascular health, not just its plaques.

clusters.title: A massive ADHD study reveals what actually works
clusters.summary: A sweeping new review of ADHD treatments—drawing on more than 200 meta-analyses—cuts through years of mixed messaging and hype. To make sense of it all, researchers have launched an interactive, public website that lets people with ADHD and clinicians explore what actually works, helping them make clearer, evidence-based decisions—while also highlighting a major gap: most solid evidence only covers short-term effects, even though long-term treatment is common.

items.title: A massive ADHD study reveals what actually works
items.description: A sweeping new review of ADHD treatments—drawing on more than 200 meta-analyses—cuts through years of mixed messaging and hype. To make sense of it all, researchers have launched an interactive, public website that lets people with ADHD and clinicians explore what actually works, helping them make clearer, evidence-based decisions—while also highlighting a major gap: most solid evidence only covers short-term effects, even though long-term treatment is common.

clusters.title: Popular acid reflux medication linked to anemia and bone loss
clusters.summary: Popular acid reflux drugs such as Prilosec, Nexium, and Protonix may carry hidden risks when taken long term. A new study found that extended use disrupted iron and calcium levels in rats, changes associated with anemia and osteoporosis risk. Researchers also observed shifts in mineral balance across multiple organs.

items.title: Popular acid reflux medication linked to anemia and bone loss
items.description: Popular acid reflux drugs such as Prilosec, Nexium, and Protonix may carry hidden risks when taken long term. A new study found that extended use disrupted iron and calcium levels in rats, changes associated with anemia and osteoporosis risk. Researchers also observed shifts in mineral balance across multiple organs. Experts say the medications are effective, but prolonged use without medical guidance could have unintended consequences.

clusters.title: A blood marker could predict how people respond to antidepressants
clusters.summary: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is among the most common psychiatric disorders, affecting approximately 330 people worldwide. This disorder is characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, low motivation, a loss of interest in daily activities, and possible disruptions in sleep and/or appetite changes.

items.title: A blood marker could predict how people respond to antidepressants
items.description: Major depressive disorder (MDD) is among the most common psychiatric disorders, affecting approximately 330 people worldwide. This disorder is characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, low motivation, a loss of interest in daily activities, and possible disruptions in sleep and/or appetite changes.

clusters.title: That dry, bitter taste may be waking up your brain
clusters.summary: New research suggests the astringent sensation caused by flavanols could act as a direct signal to the brain, triggering effects similar to a mild workout for the nervous system. In mouse experiments, flavanol intake boosted activity, curiosity, learning, and memory—despite these compounds barely entering the bloodstream. The key appears to be sensory stimulation: the taste itself activates brain pathways linked to attention, motivation, and stress response, lighting up regions involved in arousal and memory.

items.title: That dry, bitter taste may be waking up your brain
items.description: New research suggests the astringent sensation caused by flavanols could act as a direct signal to the brain, triggering effects similar to a mild workout for the nervous system. In mouse experiments, flavanol intake boosted activity, curiosity, learning, and memory—despite these compounds barely entering the bloodstream. The key appears to be sensory stimulation: the taste itself activates brain pathways linked to attention, motivation, and stress response, lighting up regions involved in arousal and memory.

clusters.title: Habit-like repetition influences decisions more than previously thought, large-scale study finds
clusters.summary: Why do people often make decisions in the same pattern and choose the tried and tested, even when there are apparently better alternatives? A research team led by Stefan Kiebel, Professor of Cognitive Computational Neuroscience at TUD, investigated this question in a large-scale study. To this end, the team examined nine newly collected decision-making tasks and six previously published data sets with a total of over 700 participants to determine how people initially learn values in clearly defined decision-making contexts and which of these learned options they subsequently prefer in newly combined contexts.

items.title: Habit-like repetition influences decisions more than previously thought, large-scale study finds
items.description: Why do people often make decisions in the same pattern and choose the tried and tested, even when there are apparently better alternatives? A research team led by Stefan Kiebel, Professor of Cognitive Computational Neuroscience at TUD, investigated this question in a large-scale study. To this end, the team examined nine newly collected decision-making tasks and six previously published data sets with a total of over 700 participants to determine how people initially learn values in clearly defined decision-making contexts and which of these learned options they subsequently prefer in newly combined contexts.

clusters.title: After total pancreatectomy, most endocrine crises hit within three months
clusters.summary: After undergoing a total pancreatectomy, where the pancreas is surgically removed in its entirety, many patients face potentially life-threatening endocrine complications like hypoglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis. This is because the pancreas plays a key role in regulating blood sugar levels. It is unclear, however, whether those complications differ between the different types of total pancreatectomy.

items.title: After total pancreatectomy, most endocrine crises hit within three months
items.description: After undergoing a total pancreatectomy, where the pancreas is surgically removed in its entirety, many patients face potentially life-threatening endocrine complications like hypoglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis. This is because the pancreas plays a key role in regulating blood sugar levels. It is unclear, however, whether those complications differ between the different types of total pancreatectomy. In a publication in Surgery, researchers at Thomas Jefferson University found that patients who received a single-stage total pancreatectomy, where the entire organ is completely removed, faced higher rates of endocrine complications than those who had a completion or two-stage pancreatectomy, where the remainder of the pancreas is removed after a previous partial pancreatectomy.
